debate.para: The following bill was returned from the Senate without amendment or request:

debateinfo.title: ENVIRONMENT AND HERITAGE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (APPLICATION OF CRIMINAL CODE) BILL 2000

subdebate.1.para: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.
Ordered that the second reading be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

talk.start.para: —I did move in relation to this bill that:

quote.para: “whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for its ... taxation indexation policies ...”

speech.para: I guess the tax indexation policy that has been vexing people most in recent times is that which relates to petrol. Everyone here will recall the Prime Minister's pre-election promise that petrol taxes would not rise as a result of the GST. In fact they have risen, and some estimates within the automotive industry suggest that the additional windfall revenue is of the order of as much as $1.5 billion per annum. One of the elements of significance of that windfall is that the Commonwealth government, the Howard government says, `Oh, but this is okay because we are compensating people with a roads funding package.' In fact, if you examine that roads funding package you will find it is only $400 million per year as against a $1.5 billion windfall through additional petrol taxes.

Indeed, their taxation indexation policies are such that this is the fourth rise in petrol taxes in seven months. We had the GST come in on 1 July. That exceeded the drop in excise by a good 1½c a litre. We then had the August round of petrol excise indexation. Later in the year there was an increase as the general price of petrol increased. The goods and services tax kicked in. It is a retail tax that kicked in to increase the level of petrol costs still further. Then we had the 1 February excise rise of the order of 1.7c per litre. So now we have a situation with petrol taxes of the GST and excise, a tax on a tax, each feeding off the other in a vicious inflationary spiral. For the first time we have country petrol taxes higher than city petrol taxes, and we have a situation with a retail tax where, every time the international price increases, the tax increases still further. That is the reason Labor has sent out its petrol inquiry around Australia into the rural and regional areas, and that is the reason we have moved a private member's bill. I hope the government will change its mind and start supporting that bill instead of opposing it. That is the reason we moved our amendment here condemning the government for its tax indexation policies. I hope that that will be supported here as well. As I indicated earlier, we are not opposing the bill before the House. It simply continues policies which Labor embarked upon in government, and we have no objection to this legislation.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

—The Medicare Levy Amendment (CPI Indexation) Bill (No. 2) 2000 seeks to amend the Medicare Levy Act which was passed by this parliament in 1986. As members know, that act exempts low income individuals and families from the levy. In addition, an individual member of a couple who does not have adequate private hospital cover is exempt from the Medicare levy surcharge where the total of that person's taxable income and reportable fringe benefits is below the individual Medicare levy low income threshold. The bill—which of course I strongly support, and I know it is supported by the opposition—provides for increases in the low income threshold to further protect those individuals and couples because of the fact that the thresholds have not had the benefit of the CPI indexation which has occurred. This bill will increase the thresholds for the 1.9 per cent CPI increase for the year to 31 March.

speech.para: So the bill, while relatively simple, is an important one. The member for Wills—and I thank the member for Wills for his courtesy in advising me of the length of his speech so that I was aware of that and ready to speak now—has confirmed that the Labor Party's policy is in fact to support the principle of indexation, in this case to protect low income people and ensure that the threshold is at the appropriate level so that low income people do not get themselves into a position where they are required to pay the levy. Incidentally it also highlights the fact that the Labor Party's posturing and stunting this week and in previous weeks leading up to this parliament about fuel excise are of course a lot of humbug. Why? Because the Labor Party introduced indexation for petrol excise in Australia. It is their own idea; it has been part of their policy for years and years.

The reason for this is based on the sound principle that, even though an excise is an unpopular tax—and I concede that; people do not like paying taxes and excises; I know that—the revenue streams of the Commonwealth go to pay pensions, to pay the states the agreed amounts for Medicare so that public hospitals and Medicare can be maintained, to ensure that the states receive an appropriate additional amount from the Commonwealth so that services for disabled people and their families can be maintained, and to enable the states to receive extra funds from the Commonwealth so that public housing provided by the states is maintained at a real level, taking into account inflation. That is the reason. So the purpose of fuel excise indexation introduced by Labor governments of bygone days is to ensure that the amount collected for excise, even though it is an unpopular thing, maintains its value compared to the performance of the economy in relation to inflation. If it were otherwise, the income stream of the Commonwealth would be so affected—because it did not have indexation—that the Commonwealth would not be able to honour its obligations and deliver additional moneys as part of the revenue stream to maintain pensions.

Let me give you an example, one that I am sure all members would embrace and would not want to see undermined. The Howard government, when it put tax reform to the Australian people at the last election, said that by reason of tax reform and the introduction of the GST there would be a disadvantage to low income people and people on pensions and social security allowances. That was a core promise by John Howard, and he has honoured that. He ensured that when the tax reform package eventually went through—and I think it was supported by Labor and the other parties in the Senate as a basic core issue that should not be eroded—pensions would increase by an additional amount of four per cent, because of that once-off introduction of GST, to ensure that more than adequate extra pension payments were made.

I think that is common ground; I think I have given an accurate summary of what occurred. Prior to that, the Howard government made a historic decision and introduced legislation, which is now law, that also said that the rate of pension payable to pensioners in Australia, to further protect them against inflation, should be based on a formula where that rate should not ever be less than 25 per cent of average male wages in Australia. That was a historic move by the Howard government, one that is applauded and appreciated by many families in Australia. It was the first time ever that a government had made sure that pensions would at least be maintained at a level which would relate to average male weekly wages in Australia.

Of course all of us would hope that one day the economy and the Commonwealth and society would be able to afford to further increase pensions for our seniors who helped build this country and for other people who need a helping hand under the social security system because they are going through difficult times. I am not for one moment suggesting that this should always be frozen in time, but I think it was a terrific initiative of the Howard government to get pensions up to the level where they can never fall below that rate of 25 per cent of average male weekly wages. That was a fantastic breakthrough.

If the country is well managed and continues to prosper, and people work together and accept mutual responsibility, there is no reason to suggest that Australia's wealth and resources will not enable us—I know I will not be in the parliament, because I am retiring, but other future parliamentarians—to further increase the percentage of average weekly male earnings, because we will be able to afford to do so. In the meantime it is terribly important that members of parliament have the courage to explain to the community that, where the revenue dependency of governments of whatever political colour is based on a system of collection of revenue under a tax system which includes excise, then, because petrol excise is a volumetric excise—it is not based on the price at the pump, contrary to suggestions by some of the Labor members in the community—

talk.start.para: —The GST is.

—No, it is not. The GST is, but I am talking about the excise—please understand, I am not misrepresenting the position. The excise is based on the volumetric sale at the pump, so it is always frozen and fixed. Unfortunately the world price of petrol is forcing up Australian prices at the pump, from around 80c to over $1 at one stage. Thank goodness in Wangaratta yesterday the price was 89.5c due to Howard government policies and good retailing—smart retailing—by new independent competitors.

speech.para: My point is that the excise on fuel needs to be indexed because it does not increase along with the price at the pump. The value of the 10 per cent GST take increases as the price of petrol goes up, but the excise—which is 40-odd cents per litre—is frozen. That is why the indexation system applies. The debate rages about whether the Prime Minister should reduce excise on a one-off basis, but, in reality, that would take about $500 million or $600 million from the revenue stream. The revenue from the indexation of excise is used to honour our promise to pensioners and to the states under the Medicare public hospital system that they will receive regular, agreed, real term amounts from the Commonwealth.

The Labor Party stands condemned for its approach. If it does not like the rate of excise for whatever reason, it has a duty to advocate that dislike by all means, but it also has a duty and a responsibility to explain what new tax or reduction in services—in health, education, defence or whatever—it will propose instead.

talk.start.para: —There is ample windfall.

—No, Labor has a duty to spell out either its ideas for some new tax to replace the revenue stream or its intention to cut a service—albeit an essential service—to do that. We have not had any such revelation from the Labor Party; instead we have had much waffle and stunting. This week the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow Treasurer conceded during their speeches on matters of public importance that they could not reveal the position of the alternative government. I think the Leader of the Opposition said, `I'll have to wait until I get the budget papers and then I'll make up my mind'. Intellectually, that means that the Leader of the Opposition might not do anything or he might do something. In the meantime, he is going around Australia saying, `The excise! The indexation! Howard should give it back'. That is nonsense; it is an insult to the Australian people.

speech.para: The Australian people do not buy it. Opposition members might think they are gaining ground on this issue. Of course there is an adverse public reaction initially because no one likes high fuel prices—it is an emotional issue. However, the people of Australia will not forgive Labor at the ballot box. During 13 years in government, Labor increased excise—the rate of excise not just indexation—by 450 per cent. The Prime Minister has not increased the rate of excise. During his term of office the rate of excise has increased only as a result of indexation. The Australian people will have that fact well and truly in their minds—mark my words. Those Australians listening to this broadcast know the truth: the Leader of the Opposition has not told them what he will do to replace the revenue stream—in fact, he has said, `I can't tell you and I won't tell you'. He has put all sorts of caveats on his failure to respond. Judging Labor on its past form, it will use excise as a means of extracting income to pay for recurrent expenditure and other capital works. That caused great financial problems during Labor's 13 years in government: it drove up interest rates and inflation and left us with a $10.3 billion deficit. Government debt rose to $70 billion. That is the contrast.

The debate on this legislation is unique because the Labor Party has pulled all sorts of stunts this week. The opposition says, `Yes, we support indexing the thresholds of Medicare levy exemptions'—it must do so because it is Labor policy and it is important to protect low income earners. Today's debate about the exemption highlights Labor's humbug, hypocrisy and stunting on the difficult, emotional issue of high fuel prices. Fuel prices are high—we regret that. However, not once this week have I heard a single opposition member explain that the real reason for high fuel prices—thankfully, they have decreased a little recently—is the increased world price, which rose from $US11 a barrel eighteen months ago to more than $US30 in the past few months. Not once did Labor members say, `Look, you have to take account of the real reason for fluctuating fuel prices: the problem with OPEC'.

That is the main issue. We all do our best internationally. I hope that the new President of the United States and leaders of other countries will continue their efforts to persuade OPEC to adopt a more reasonable policy in respect of world parity pricing. I understand that the ALP—the alternative government—does not resile from its long-held policy of supporting world parity pricing. I have not heard Labor members say that they will change their stance. That is the truth of the matter: the high price of fuel in Australia is due largely to high world oil prices. Of course the price of fuel is too high; we want it to be lower. However, that revenue stream from the Commonwealth must pay for the indexation of pensions and public hospitals under the Medicare system. The opposition wants to see that funding threatened. We must draw that conclusion because Labor members have not given a reason—other than stunting—for their position or explained it. Opposition members have spoken a lot of waffle. I support the bill.

talk.start.para: —Since the Medicare Levy Amendment (CPI Indexation) Bill (No. 2) 2000 indexes the threshold for the Medicare levy and since that indexation is Labor Party policy, begun by the Labor Party, naturally we support the legislation, just as we support the second reading amendment to the legislation. I particularly wish to speak, as did the previous speaker, the honourable member for Indi, about that part of the second reading amendment which condemns the government for its taxation indexation policies and their effect on the community.

speech.para: The latest increase in petrol taxes occurred on 1 February. It was the fourth increase in petrol taxes in just seven months and it was a result of the indexation of the excise on petrol. Incidentally, the same indexation policies have led to an increase in the price of cigarettes and alcohol. The overwhelming proportion of the indexation increase is directly attributable to the GST—that is, on 1 July last year the GST came in and became a major contributor to inflation over the six months to the end of December. That inflation has led to an automatic increase in the indexation of excise for petrol, alcohol and tobacco.

What we have now is an insidious policy of the GST and the excise being a tax on a tax—something this government said would never happen. It said that it would not have a tax on a tax. But, worse than that, the GST itself is forcing up inflation; the inflation is then forcing up the excise. So we have the GST and the excise acting as a tax on a tax, each forcing the other up in a vicious inflationary spiral. Our argument has been that this excise increase on fuel should be abandoned. To that intent on several occasions we have sought to introduce a private member's bill that would have abandoned that fuel excise increase.

As I foreshadowed, I wish to make some remarks about some members opposite in respect of their attitude to that legislation—that is, the legislation that would have given some relief to struggling motorists all around Australia. One of the members who have voted against the introduction of that legislation is the member for Sturt. In his own area, as a result of the excise increases on fuel that occurred on 1 February, motorists in suburbs such as Northfield, Norwood, Kensington and Glenside are now paying 48.2c a litre in petrol taxes. That means that an average motorist in the electorate of Sturt using a 50 litre tank of petrol a week is now paying $24 a week in petrol taxes, or $1,250 a year. As I indicated, this is the fourth increase in petrol taxes in just seven months under this government.

The government is kidding when it says that the GST has played no part in raising petrol prices. The government pretends that it has all been due to world oil prices going up and the very weak Australian dollar. But, as I said, most of the February excise increase was due to the inflationary effects of the GST. Yet, when announcing the GST before the last election in his address to the nation, the Prime Minister made this pledge to the people of Australia:

quote.para: The GST will not increase the price of petrol for the ordinary motorist.

speech.para: The people of Sturt and the people of Australia know that the Prime Minister has broken his promise. I call on the member for Sturt to explain to the people of his electorate why he has failed to represent their interests and support our position, which was not to proceed with the excise increase on 1 February.

talk.start.para: (Mr Nehl)—Order! The honourable member for Rankin will resume his seat. I feel it incumbent on me, in view of my need to observe and support the standing orders, to point out that we are debating the Medicare Levy Amendment (CPI Indexation) Bill (No. 2) 2000 and his comments must be related to the content of the bill. There is no way that comments about petrol taxation can be taken into the Medicare bill. I invite him to continue but to restrict his remarks to the content of the bill.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I draw your attention to the second reading amendment to the bill, which states:

quote.para: ... whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for its treatment of Medicare and effective Americanisation of the health system and its taxation indexation policies and their effect on the community ...

speech.para: The previous speaker was speaking to the second reading amendment as well because he spent most of his speech talking about petrol taxation. Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask only that fair treatment be given. If the government member wishes to speak to the second reading amendment, which is about the indexation policies of the government, I have the right to speak to that same second reading amendment.

What I am saying is that the taxation indexation of excise should not have proceeded on 1 February. The fact that it has means that not only the member for Sturt but all of those members of parliament on the government side who in their electorates have said that they are very concerned about rising fuel taxes and about the excise increase proceeding—and who believe that some relief should be given to motorists—are tigers in their electorates but cowards when they come to Canberra. In the last two days we have given government members ample opportunity to support our private member's bill, which would abandon the fuel excise increase.

We should at least be able to ask the government to be consistent on these matters. If it is going to index thresholds like the Medicare levy, with which we agree, and if it is going to proceed with the full indexation of excise on fuel, alcohol and tobacco, it should also index pensions. The next pension rise occurs on 31 March. But what is going to happen on 31 March? Whatever the CPI increase is for the relevant period, the government will be taking two percentage points off it. So it is going to discount the pension rise. We are only asking for fair treatment. We are saying, `Discount and, in fact, abandon the fuel excise increase.' The government says, `No, we won't do that. We won't discount our tax rises, but we will discount pension rises.'

What is fair about that? Did the people of Australia, when they voted at the last election, understand that pensioners would be facing a discount on the indexation of their pensions on 31 March? When you ask the government why it is going ahead with a discount on the pension indexation rise, the answer is, `Because we have over-compensated pensioners.' There are plenty of pensioners in my electorate to whom I have spoken, and when I say to them, `The reason you are going to have a discount on your pension rise on 31 March is that the government has decided that you have been over-compensated for the GST', those pensioners get very angry.

The pensioners in the electorate of Rankin, particularly in areas like Woodridge and Kingston, Slacks Creek, Marsden and Crestmead, do not believe for a moment that they have been overcompensated for the effects of the GST. They have not been overcompensated. They are struggling and they are very unhappy. They are very unhappy because they are now worse off already as a result of the so-called `streamlined new tax system for a new century'. The debacle of the savings bonus has made them even angrier. Many pensioners in my electorate got a bonus payment that they thought—and were told before the election—would be $1,000 and they got just $1.

The next insult to pensioners in Australia is coming on 31 March, when the government is going to discount the pension rise. So, if the pension rise were to be four per cent, it is only going to be two per cent. Once pensioners realise the betrayal by this government of their living standards, they will be very angry indeed. So I call on the government to be consistent in its treatment of the GST and to be fair in its treatment of this so-called `streamlined new tax system for a new century'.

I have just been advised that the Liberal backbencher and member for McEwen is calling for a general review of petrol taxes. She has said on Perth radio that we need to look seriously at the whole question of the excise. So here we have more breaking of rank by government members. But when the same member comes into this parliament and has an opportunity to be a tiger not only in her electorate but in Canberra, that member is not a tiger. The member is a coward in Canberra and a tiger in her electorate. What we have been doing is exposing the duplicity of those members who say one thing in their electorates and do another thing here in Canberra.

The whole impact of the GST was supposed to be to create jobs to foster economic growth. It has been quite the opposite. The unemployment figures today show that the GST is destroying jobs. It is destroying jobs, as predicted by Professor Peter Dixon. When he was asked in evidence before the Senate inquiry into the GST he said that the GST is `job destroying'. Professor Dixon, with today's figures, has proved to be correct.

Let us understand this. Let us make no mistake. The slowdown in the Australian economy is self-inflicted. It is remarkable that when economic growth is going ahead the government claims credit for it, but when economic growth starts to slow, the government says it is international factors—that it is the American economy, or high world oil prices. The economic slowdown in this country is self-inflicted by one large internal shock—and that is the GST.

Mr Greenspan's support for the Bush administration's income tax cuts will thrill the Howard government because the Treasurer is a great fan of cutting the highest marginal rate of income tax. He has declared himself an income tax cut man who would want to see the income tax threshold for the highest rate of tax pushed out to multiples of average weekly earnings. No doubt he will try to cloak his plan with the respectability of responsible macro-economic management. But he cannot.

The government had an opportunity to provide a bit of stimulus to the slowing economy on 1 February by not going ahead with the fuel excise indexation increase, but it did not. What is happening in the economy is that the GST is operating in conjunction with the Australian business number to collect much larger amounts of revenue than the government had forecast and than the government is prepared to admit. As a result of the operation of the GST and the Australian business number, there is a fiscal contraction going on in this country. We have had a monetary contraction until recently, with progressive cuts and increases in interest rates, all of which to try to ensure that there were no wage flow-ons from the GST; that is, effectively, that wages were not indexed for the GST. The government does not want wages to be indexed for the GST, so it screwed down the economy with tight monetary policy and, because the GST is collecting a lot more revenue than the government is prepared to admit, we have had in the last few months both a tight monetary policy and a tight fiscal policy.

As a result of that, the government itself has engineered an economic slowdown. That slowdown will be compounded by the rapidly slowing American economy but that external shock has not yet fully arrived in Australia. Australia's economic slowdown, therefore, is directly attributable to the GST. The celebrations of a smooth transition have turned sour, as small businesses struggle with their second business activity statement. Small businesses try to hold enough cash in reserve to cope with a rainy day. Many of them used those reserves to pay their first quarterly GST instalment. But, fearful of losing market share if they jacked up prices to meet their GST liabilities, small businesses have taken a cut in margins instead. That helps explain the 0.3 per cent December quarter CPI rise. With those cash reserves depleted and GST liabilities mounting, not to mention the paperwork associated with the business activity statement, small businesses that have operated close to the margin are at risk of going under. Many businesses are going under. I was amused to read in the member for Sturt's first speech, in 1993, that he said:

quote.para: I was responsible for helping to establish new businesses and trying to save existing firms from bankruptcy.

speech.para: It is a pity he does not try to save a few firms from bankruptcy now, because firms are going bankrupt because of the operation of the GST. He, along with other members of the government, has done nothing to try to relieve the GST paperwork burden, the business activity statement. I call on the member for Sturt and all other government members to simplify the operation of the business activity statement. We have opened that agenda. It is a Labor agenda that the business activity statement should be simplified, and the government is saying, `We might make one major simplification: we might take out the box for the wine equalisation tax and we might take out the box for the luxury car tax.'

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The member addressing the chamber is straying very widely from the subject matter of the bill and also from the amendment currently before the House. I would ask you to ask him to bring himself back to the subject matter.

—I thank the parliamentary secretary. He should be aware that the chair has already canvassed this with the member for Rankin and that the amendment which is under discussion does include the words `and its taxation indexation policies', which broadens it to virtually allow anything.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. That was the intent of the second reading amendment, and it is a pity that the parliamentary secretary had not read it. He should do his homework. The GST is causing a contraction in this economy. There was an opportunity for the government to provide some relief on 1 February by not going ahead with the fuel excise indexation increase, but it failed that opportunity and, in so doing, it failed the people of Australia.

speech.para: GST receipts for the current financial year were revised upwards in the midyear outlook by $2.25 billion. There will be more coming. I suspect it is raining money. I suspect it is raining GST money and that that is causing the contraction that we are now experiencing in the Australian economy. As a result of this, there will be bankruptcies. There already are bankruptcies—they are on the rise—and, as we go further through the year, there are going to be even more. What will happen, I fear, is that, in the May budget, when it is too late, the government will say, `Alan Greenspan got it right in America. He gave some support to the Bush administration's income tax cuts. We had better provide a little fiscal stimulus too. We will announce a new round of income tax cuts for high income earners.' That is the Treasurer's agenda: not income tax cuts for all but income tax cuts for high income earners. He will cloak this in this respectability of sound macroeconomic management.

When the Prime Minister was repeatedly asked in this parliament and in the media towards the end of last year why he would not support an abandoning of the fuel excise indexation increase on 1 February, the answer he gave was that it would force up interest rates. How quickly times have changed. It was not a valid explanation then and it is a disastrous explanation now because, as the Prime Minister would know, the direction on interest rates is down. The American Federal Reserve has cut interest rates in a very short space of time by two lots of 0.5 per cent, by half a percentage point; and, similarly, the Reserve Bank of Australia have now cut interest rates because they are so concerned about the fiscal contraction in this country from the wound that has been inflicted on this country by the GST and by this government's economic mismanagement.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Fuel Excise

talk.start.para: —The opposition's claim that they want to cut petrol taxes and roll back the GST is nothing more than a political stunt. I say that because, in spite of countless opportunities, the Leader of the Opposition will not give a guarantee to the Australian public that if he were to become Prime Minister he would cancel the indexation of the fuel excise. In fact, the complete opposite is the case. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition confirmed this on ABC radio when he said:

quote.para: We're not proposing to make any changes to the fuel excise regime.

speech.para: Not one member of the opposition will make a commitment to reform the indexation of the excise and, even worse than this, their candidate in McEwen went on the public record via ABC radio just last week that he will not even fight against any future excise rise on petrol. He will not even raise a whimper of protest and yet at the same time they expect people to believe they are sincere about cutting petrol taxes and rolling back the GST. The opposition have sat back for five years and they have not developed any policy at all. They say in here, where they know that they will not succeed, that they want to cut this petrol tax but outside this place—

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: I draw your attention to standing order 82, that no member `may anticipate discussion of any subject which appears on the NoticePaper'. In fact, the Leader of the Opposition has a private member's bill which deals with exactly this issue and is seeking to remove this round of petrol excise.
(Mr Nehl)—There is no point of order.

—They say in here, where they know they will not succeed, that they want to cut petrol tax, but outside this place they say they have no plans to change the fuel excise system. On the one hand, they say that they want to provide relief of 1.4c on a litre of petrol but, on the other hand, they say that they will cut the 1c and 2c country fuel subsidy. They cannot have it both ways. Their stance on fuel is the height of hypocrisy, and that is why what they are doing is nothing more than a stunt—a stunt that I would never support. I want relief for the people I represent who are struggling: the pensioners, who are on low, fixed incomes; families who are trying to balance their budgets on $30,000 a year; the self-funded retirees who worked hard all their lives, paid their taxes and now find it tough living on tight budgets. If the fuel excise system cannot be changed in the short term because the revenue raised from the excise is paying for a range of services including health, education and roads, then I want to see some relief for those struggling through both our welfare and taxation systems.

speech.para: Another aspect of this whole fuel debate which is not being highlighted is the role of the oil companies. Prior to the February indexation adjustments of 1½c per litre, across my electorate fuel was selling for around 84.9c a litre. After the 1½c indexation, it has been selling for around 97.9c a litre. A difference of 13c a litre is not the result of an increased indexation of 1½c per litre. I have to say that obtaining information from oil companies is more difficult than extracting teeth. However, industry sources have advised me that the average wholesale price per litre of fuel in early 1999 was 14c a litre. That has risen to a high of 40c a litre in 2001 because of OPEC policy and the value of the Australian dollar. Even if petrol were purchased at this high wholesale figure—and this is not consistent—and with the excise currently at 39.6c a litre, there certainly is a very big gap, and it is the motorist who is paying that gap—a gap which cannot be explained by transport costs, distribution costs or the GST. It is just impossible to believe that the oil companies are working on wafer-thin profit margins, and it certainly is not the service station owners who are the ones making the big profits. I have always believed that the fuel excise system lacks equity, because those who live and work outside metropolitan areas pay a disproportionate amount of the excise simply because they need more vehicles per household, they use more fuel and they do not have access to regular public transport. While acknowledging the importance of how the revenue raised by the excise is used, I do believe that there is a need for a full inquiry into the excise. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I have, on a number of occasions, raised my concerns about the growing trend towards the privatisation of policing, law enforcement and detention facilities in Australia. In that context, I want to raise my concerns about the decision of the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs to extend the contract for the management of Australia's detention centres of the company Australasian Correctional Management Pty Ltd, or ACM, by an additional 12 months, notwithstanding the series of very serious allegations that have been directed against its existing management. I have a number of questions that I think need to be answered in this parliament. Firstly, the minister has said:

quote.para: ... [although ACM] is a wholly owned subsidiary of Wackenhut Corrections Corporation, it is an Australian company operating in the Australian environment and according to Australian laws ... [and] according to Australian management principles and practice.

speech.para: But three out of four of ACM's directors are Americans, based in Florida along with Wackenhut Corrections. That is the parent organisation, and, when ACM was sued for negligence over unsafe work practices in the Arthur Gorrie correctional facility in 1994, it was not the Australian director but one of the Florida directors who was sent to Australia to defend its management practices. The first ACM general manager of Arthur Gorrie was a former US marine colonel, who had to be replaced following a prison riot in 1993. The man behind the Wackenhut organisation and essentially the management controller of ACM is a man called George Wackenhut, a former FBI agent who has been described as `a rightist of the old blood who selected as his directors an assortment of ultras prominent in the John Birch Society and other right-wing groups'. George Wackenhut has been reported as saying:

quote.para: Australian operations are very important to us ...

speech.para: And:

quote.para: They're really starting to punish people the way they should have done all along.

speech.para: The minister really has to answer how he can assert that ACM is an Australian company operating according to Australian management practices and principles.

Worse than the matters that I have raised is the issue of its management and its control as an overseas corporation. That overseas corporation has a poor record. The American company that fully owns ACM has had to surrender the contract to run a prison in Texas following investigations into allegations of criminal activity and sex between guards and inmates within the prison. It has had to settle out of court with the family of a 14-year-old girl who was raped almost every night by a security guard in a Wackenhut run juvenile justice centre. That girl subsequently committed suicide. At a work release facility run by Wackenhut in Fort Lauderdale, it has had to fire or punish five guards for having sex with inmates last year. Most importantly in the Australian context, Wackenhut Corrections, which is the sole owner of the contractor in control of the Woomera Detention Centre, was sued by the US Department of Justice on the grounds that Wackenhut security officers in a juvenile prison in Louisiana repeatedly sexually and physically abused minors in that facility and that Wackenhut Corrections subjected juveniles to corporal punishment, excessive force, gas grenades, chemical restraints and inadequate medical and mental health services, with the result that Louisiana has now been prohibited from placing any more juveniles in the prison run by Wackenhut Corrections.

It is in that context that I am extremely concerned by the proposal put forward by the minister to give security staff in the ACM facilities the power to chemically restrain asylum seekers. This is not a matter which I treat lightly. It would be a disturbing power even if it were given to those with direct accountability to a parliament through a minister, but when it is being conferred on a private organisation under the direct ownership of a company with that kind of record I regard it as a very serious and disturbing matter indeed. I think that all Australians were concerned when we heard reports from Russia where a woman was allegedly forcibly sedated after showing her distress at the death of her former husband in a submarine that sank. Whilst no-one in this House would wish to condone illegal or difficult behaviour by people in detention in any facility, it is inappropriate that those models of detention are utilised in Australia. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Banking: Commonwealth Bank Branch Closure, Wanniassa

talk.start.para: —Tonight I want to talk about the Commonwealth Bank and its actions within my electorate. On 1 December I had a letter delivered to me by the Commonwealth Bank regional management who look after the area of my constituency to notify me that the Wanniassa branch was going to close on 12 January. The letter from the Commonwealth Bank referred to the fact that they were planning to close the Wanniassa branch of their bank in my electorate as from 12 January 2001. The decision to close the bank was outlined to me in the letter from the management of the bank, and I would like to refer to that if I may. They said to me:

quote.para: On Friday, 12 January 2001, the Commonwealth Bank's Wanniassa branch will cease operations.
The decision to close this branch was taken only after a thorough investigation of many factors, including both current and future business trends, customer usage and the alternative services.

speech.para: What they did not mention in that particular letter were the needs of their customers—a bank that made $2.7 billion profit in the financial year just ended, just under twice the profit of $1.422 billion of the previous year. Do they have a responsibility to their shareholders? They certainly do. But do they have a responsibility to their customers? I believe that they absolutely do. I wrote back to the bank immediately outlining why I believed the closure should not go ahead. I got a letter back from the bank, and I would like to share some of the contents of that letter with the House:

quote.para: The decision to close this branch was taken only after a thorough investigation of all factors affecting the Commonwealth Banks business. ... I realise that our decision will inconvenience some clients, despite the availability of alternatives outlined in my letter of 1st of December 2000.

speech.para: The writer of the letter went on to say:

quote.para: People who still use passbooks for over the counter withdrawals may be impacted by the branch closure. Card access to accounts is a viable and greatly enhanced economic alternative to our customers. The pricing of our product range is geared to offer substantial savings to our customers who use card based electronic mechanisms and there is genuine financial gain and convenience for our customers.

speech.para: What they do not mention is the inconvenience to customers who, in fact, cannot use those forms of banking. They go on to say:

quote.para: ... all banking business can be conducted by telephone, Internet, or through a branch Network ...

speech.para: and so on. But what about those customers who cannot use those facilities: the young boy who came to a rally outside the bank—in fact, it was the last day of sitting of this House and I went down and met them that morning; he was enjoying the experience of learning the business of banking from the local manager—or the woman who came up to see me that morning who is visually impaired and finds it very physically convenient to be able to go to a local branch? The social obligations on banks must be recognised. If banks will not do it, in government we will make them do it. We do not want to re-regulate banks, but we certainly want to make sure that banks understand fully the responsibility they have to their client base. As a Mrs L. from Wanniassa said to me in a letter dated 8 December 2000:

quote.para: One of my major concerns with the branch closure is the effect the news has had on my elderly parents-in-law. They cannot walk well now, can no longer drive and have relied on our local branch to do their banking.

speech.para: A woman sent me a note on 7 December 2000:

quote.para: I feel the closure of the CBA Wanniassa branch is another nail in the coffin for small community shopping centres. Small businesses, school canteens and other industries which still conduct cash businesses need personal service not a “hole in the wall”—

speech.para: or a phone on the desk. It is about time the banks—and I could pick on all of them, not just the Commonwealth, but it is the Commonwealth in this instance that I am referring to—were forced to realise the social obligations they have to the people of the Australian community who have made banks what they are; that is, their normal customers. There is a very big move in my community to try and establish a community bank as a result of this decision and I wish that community committee well. (Time expired)

In the longer term, Australians will pay more if Australian producers like Golden Circle are forced out of the market. Golden Circle directly employs over 1,600 people and is responsible for the employment of many thousands more in local small businesses. The artificially low prices of imported solid pack pineapple and pineapple concentrate are undermining fair trade and threatening the future of the pineapple industry in Queensland.

Golden Circle has lodged a submission with the Australian Customs Service, which will bring down an interim finding by 24 April. I urge the Minister for Justice and Customs to take seriously Golden Circle's case and to put an end to the importation of this dumped product. By signing my petition supporting Golden Circle, local residents can take a positive step in assisting the company by demonstrating the strength of our local support as well as sending a clear message to the minister.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 19 June 2000.

quote.para: (1) At how many of 1,000 seminars conducted around Australia as part of the Australian Tax Offices GST communication and education campaign was there a capacity to translate questions or answers into languages other than English.
(2) How many staff are available to translate or answer questions in languages other than English during the 159 000 calls to call centres made each month in 2000.
(3) How many of the 9 million booklets sent to every household and business in Australia have contained information in languages other than English.

(4) How many of 27 different print advertisements that appeared 81 times across 9 rural newspapers, 542 times across 31 metropolitan papers, 4866 times in 394 regional papers, and 1266 times in suburban metropolitan papers, have been in languages other than English.

(5) How many television advertisements which have run on 15 metropolitan and 22 regional stations and radio advertisements for 29 metropolitan and 193 regional radio stations, have been in languages other than English.
(6) How many of the 34 million hits on the ATO website could have accessed information in languages other than English.
(7) How many of the 2.4 million new tax system registration kits posted out to businesses contained information in languages other than English.

talker.name: Costello, Peter, MP
Mr Costello
talker.role: Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) In recognition of the significant proportion of non-English speaking background (NESB) and culturally and linguistically diverse (CALD) businesses and individual taxpayers with limited English language skills, a NESB/CALD communication strategy has been developed to assist businesses and individual taxpayers understand and comply with The New Tax System. Both qualitative and quantitative research has been undertaken with NESB communities to understand their needs and assist with the development, implementation and on-going refinement of the communication program.

In April 2000, the ATO and the GST Start-Up Assistance Office launched their NESB/CALD strategies to Chambers of Commerce, Business Enterprise Centres, Ethnic Community Councils and Ethnic Press in each State.

Core activities complement those conducted for the mainstream community. For example, `in language' seminars have been conducted at community request in Mandarin, Cantonese, Vietnamese, Arabic, Korean, Thai and Japanese. `In language' seminars have also been conducted for non-profit groups and one-to-one advisory visits to NESB businesses have been conducted by members from the ATO's GST field teams who speak languages other than English.

(2) Call Centres are able to assist callers who do not speak English through the Telephone Interpreter Service. Generally callers who do not speak English call the Telephone Interpreter Service first, then they contact the Call Centre number and have a conference call.

(3) In recognition of the need for `in language' materials, the ATO has produced a number of translated publications. These include: Essentials 1 and Essentials 2, ABN fact sheet, PAYG fact sheet, Simplified Accounting Methods for Food Retailers, Be ready for business from 1 July and GST basics for retailers fact sheet. Products have been translated in up to 26 languages.

(4) The ATO has run advertisements in the ethnic press covering up to 25 languages. To take account of the frequency of distribution of publications and other government activity, not all mainstream advertisements were translated for the ethnic press. However, to ensure that messages were received by this audience, messages were carried as public relations in the ethnic media; for example, through the provision of information kits and translated media releases.

(5) Although no television advertisements have been translated, mainstream advertisements have been placed on SBS television, an important information source for the ATO's bilingual clients. Also, where possible, mainstream television advertisements include images of culturally and linguistically diverse business operators - making the television advertisements relevant to this client group.

Advertisements placed on ethnic radio have covered up to 33 languages. Delivery of messages on radio is through advertising and public relations activities. For example, during 2000 the ATO has run monthly shows in eight languages on SBS Radio. The shows included an element of talkback where listeners' questions were answered.

(6) Access to translated materials has been available since March 2000. The Tax Reform website (www.taxreform.ato.gov.au) has a number of key documents which have been translated into many languages. The website is linked to the Department of Family and Community Services which also has information in many languages.

(7) All of the registration packages for the New Tax system issued to businesses and other entities were in the English language. There was, however, reference at the end of each Guide to Registering for the New Tax System issued, to the availability of the Translating and Interpreting Service on telephone number 13 14 50.

As noted in (6) above, an introductory fact sheet about ABN has been translated into a range of languages other than English. Translations of the fact sheet are available on the website, as well as in the printed form. Each translated fact sheet makes reference to the availability of the Translating and Interpreting Service for further assistance.

Mr Costello

talk.start.para: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

As at 14 December 2000, the number of products listed for each sub-category were as follows:
(1)(b) and (c) It is the responsibility of software developers to run the scenario or test data to check their products.

The ATO maintains a quality assurance program that considers intelligence received regarding the performance or non-performance of registered software products. Where a product is found to contain errors, the software developer is contacted and the product is usually voluntarily de-listed until the problem is rectified.

In general, the application of fines or penalties would depend on the individual circumstances of each case. talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 3 October 2000.

quote.para: (1) What were the key findings of the valuation of Telstra in the Commonwealth's balance sheet referred to in Senate Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee Budget hearings (Senate Committee Hansard, 23 May 2000, pages 157-8).

(2) Were forward estimates of the sale cost, net income and underlying budget impact of the sale of the Commonwealth's remaining two thirds share of Telstra provided at page 2-39 of Budget Paper No.1 in 1998-99; if so, why cannot this same information be provided with respect to the sale of the Commonwealth's remaining interest in Telstra on the basis that it is commercially confidential.

talker.name: Fahey, John, MP
Mr Fahey
talker.role: Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1)The Government has decided not to change the valuation of its investment in Telstra under AAS31:

answer.para: · Firstly, valuing Telstra at historical cost - as the Government has always done - complies with the Australian Accounting Standards. This has been confirmed by the Auditor General.
· Secondly, valuation at historical cost in the GGS Financial Statements is consistent with the treatment in the Whole of Government statements.

quote.para: - This is because the Australian Accounting Standards do not permit Telstra to be valued to market value within the Whole of Government Consolidated Financial Statements (CFS).

answer.para: · Thirdly, reporting investments at historical cost is the common commercial practice of large private sector organisations, which must also report under Australian Accounting Standards.

quote.para: (2) Yes. It was deemed appropriate to include this information in the Budget papers for 1998-99 on a one-off basis. The Government decided that it would not be appropriate to provide this information in the papers for 1999-00 or 2000-01, as was the case for the Budget papers for the period up to 1997-98.

talker.name: Costello, Peter, MP
Mr Costello
talker.role: Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 November 2000:

quote.para: Has his attention been drawn to concerns expressed by financial planners that the New Business Tax System (Alienation of Personal Services Income) Act 2000 unintentionally applies to their activities when they operate similar business structures to other professions such as accountants and lawyers; if so (a) does the Government view the concerns as justified and (b) what steps will be taken to address the concerns?

talker.name: Costello, Peter, MP
Mr Costello
talker.role: Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: The Government is aware of the financial planners' concerns. The Assistant Treasurer, Government advisers and Treasury and Tax Office (ATO) officials have met with representatives of financial planners to discuss the legislation.

The personal services income legislation applies where a person obtains 80% or more of their personal services income from one entity unless the person obtains a personal services business determination from the Commissioner of Taxation. The grounds for a determination include engaging someone to perform 20% or more of the principal work and maintaining business premises that are separate from private premises of the worker (and their associates) and premises of the service acquirer (and associates).
The ATO is continuing to work with the financial planners to make their transition to the new tax system as smooth as possible.
